print_settings.Notes:: We printed at 75% infill, but less could probably work as well. We just increased the infill in case the water circulating in the water pump created more weight than expected. Print with supports so the holes don't collapse upon printing.

title: Ugra 132 GPH Water Pump Bracket for Grunblau Platform CNC

description.text:
These files are to provide adequate mounting brackets for the Grunblau Design Studio Platform CNC Kit at http://www.grunblau.com/PlatformCNC.htm

These mounts are to wrap around the Ugra Water Pump 12V 132GPH For Water Cooling System (MS-500) at https://ugracnc.com/index.php/online-store/product/classic-stripe-shirt

I designed this to mount on the back of the Z-axis 80/20 aluminum extrusions, they attach to the horizontal inset lines of the extrusion and attach via T-nuts on the inside of the extrusion.

We used the same size screws for the large holes to attach to the T-nuts that were included in the kit, but had to order more from McMaster-Carr. They are Type 316 Stainless Steel Low Profile Socket Head Cap Screw 5/16"-18 Thread, 1" Long.

The smaller holes have a 1/8" diameter, so any screw with a 1/16" radius should work and have at least a length of 3/4" length to fit a matching nut on one end to tighten up the front bracket with the back bracket.

I designed this to be in two parts because even with some variation of 3D printers and warping, the two piece design allows for a margin of error and the screws provide the tightening force around the water pump.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

75%

Notes:

We printed at 75% infill, but less could probably work as well. We just increased the infill in case the water circulating in the water pump created more weight than expected. Print with supports so the holes don't collapse upon printing.

Simple brackets I made to mount my filawinder to the wall since my boards had no built in mounting points. Enjoy!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3CoovCCiVf5
I'm a big Dark Souls fan, so why not make a weapon pedestal

While lying horizontally the PlayStation 2 slim takes up a lot more space than it has to. The PS2 is designed to also stand vertically (the logo even rotates!), but it needs a stand to hold it up.

All of the stands I could find selling online were either designed for a different revision of the PS2 slim than mine (which lacks a screw hole) or they cover the vent holes or both. After my original PS3 cooked itself to death I'm a bit paranoid about cooling, so I wanted a stand that would not only work with my PS2, but which would also allow airflow to the bottom vent.

Features of this design:

  • Easily printable -- there are absolutely no overhangs.
  • Doesn't use too much material (or printing time).
  • Provides good ventilation.
  • Provides adequate support for the PS2 so it won't tip over.
  • Matches the look of the PS2.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

We were looking at a way to build an cluster test environment for a reasonable price. Since we are a startup, funds can only be stretch so far. We came up with the idea of creating a Raspberry Pi Blade Center that would fit in our racks.

-A bunch of Raspberry Pi (Depending on the size of your Blade Center or ambitions!)
-A bunch of Micro USB Cables (to go with your bunch of Raspberry Pi)

title: DJ105 808 #16 camera mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
808 #16 camera mount for the Dj105 quadcopter. This mount requires you to remove the original case and lipo from the 808 camera and wire it directly to your flight battery. The board needs around 4.2v, you can use a 5v source with a diode to drop the voltage or and adjustable pololu. You will need to remove the lens from the board and push the lens into the lens housing, then reattach the board to the ribbon cable as you slide the board into the mount.

Finished flight weight is around 12 grams.

This mount requires you print in a flexible material such as ninjaflex or some kinda tpu.

description.text:
Dyson DC35 Replacement Clip (main body)

This replacement retaining clip is for the canister to main motor body of the Dyson DC35 handheld vacuum. It may work on other models, but this is the only one I can test with. A flange on my original had snapped, and I was able to take measurements from it and use the existing spring. If this happened to you, you know that the vacuum is useless without it.

Installation was a little tricky, but place the spring into this clip which will align with the + on the canister mount. Then position one of the clip flanges into the corner receiving hole while the clip is rotated at an angle. While pressingly down firmly, rotate the clip back into the straight position so that the other flange slides forward and clicks into place. Give the clip a few presses to make sure the spring is operating properly, then attach the canister to the motor body as usual.

title: Experimental print: spiral vase mode fan nozzle

description.text:
I came up with the glorious idea of printing a fan nozzle in Repetier's spiral vase mode. And I can report: IT ACTUALLY WORKS The only glitch I found is that the printed object is not single-walled, slic3r creates two perimeters, thus a 'hollow' fan nozzle is printed, but closed on both ends, leaving the regular holes of the fan nozzle open. So it can be used right off the printbed. Material consumption went down from 9 g to 5 g. Stability is good, and fan nozzles do not take heavy load anyway.
Printing time was less than 15 minutes, much quicker than a standard print (took ~25 minutes). For the tuning people: the fan nozzle is now transparent, would be cool to add some light effects :-)

I needed a stand for my Samsung S4 phone with installed gel protection cover. All phone stands that I could find did not allow for the extra thickness and width that the protective cover added. This is the first iteration of my home made stand. It's been in use and working well for a couple of weeks already...

Printed on Leapfrog Creatr, 0.2mm layer thickness, 2 shells, 25% infill, break-away support for part B, 1.75 mm white PLA.  
I used an HRS (Hirose) micro USB connector ZX80-B-5SA (Farnell 1719111, Mouser 798-ZX80-B-5SA, DigiKey H11612-ND). Take care when connecting this connector. The pins are very close together (0.65 mm!). Make sure that the positive and negative connections don't get swapped! If only pins 1 (VBUS) and 5 (GND) are connected your phone will charge at around 450 milli-amps, If your charger is capable of charging at 2 amps and you additionally short pins 2 (D+) and 3 (D-) it should charge at 1.5 amps. I used self tapping 3 mm screws to fix the connector. For fixing the bottom part I used two countersunk M3 bolts.  
Connect at your own risk!

The Salsero (see photo), with 16 tubes tuned to C D E F# G# Bb starting from Bb1 (the middle line of the treble clef) to high E4, gives you the loudest part of the range to let you improvise with a Cuban rhythm section without a mike. You can almose slip it in your pocket. The Alto 19, has three octaves tuned in G A B C# D# F and is an all-purpose flute, which will help players who want to wean themselves painlessly away from the diatonic instruments. Its 19 tubes cover the same range as the 22 tubes of the most popular diatonic nai. The Jazz Standard, with 22 tubes tuned to C D E F# G# Bb starting from D1 (just below the stave) gives you a 3Â½ octave range, a good compromise between speed and freedom.

This is version 2.0 of a 3-digit, base-10 register for an electromechanical computer I'm working on. It is stepper-driven, and works like a 3-digit counter, counting from 000-999 before rolling over. When all three digit wheels read '0-0-0', 3 reed switches will close and a circuit will be completed to detect the condition. 
This one uses fewer parts and has at least been slightly tested. It also has larger digit surfaces for better visibility, and comes with printable labels!

• Print out one copy of each piece, and one additional copy of the 8-tooth partial gear.

  • Mount 3 reed switches (http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10601) in reed_holder_leveler. These should be wired in-series (I basically clamped the holder piece between the 3 switches and a bit of proto-board).

  • This design assumes you have a 1/8" piece of wood between the stepper motor and the reed_holder_leveler piece, and that the motor is attached at a 45 degree angle relative to the front of the counter. Attach reed_holder_leveler to stepper motor / frame with an M3 bolt, so that it sticks up from the rear of the counter. Add an additional M3 bolt to the front of the motor to secure it.

  • Assuming that the wood frame also has a cut-out around the motor shaft such that it can lay flush against the wood, attach 2 4-40 bolts to a mounting hub (http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10006) so that they are sticking up vertically. Attach the hub to the shaft such that the back of the bolts is almost touching the motor surface.

  • Install a 1/8" magnet (http://www.sparkfun.com/products/8644) in the face of each digit wheel. Orientation really matters for some reason, so experimentally figure out which orientation of the magnet trips the reed switch at the longest distance. Press-fit should work, but adding a bit of glue will ensure the magnets don't fall out.

  • Print out the digit_wheel_label file, and cut out the labels. When you attach the labels, the "0" face should be directly opposite the face with the magnet embedded in it. I used scotch tape to attach them.

  • Install the "counter_gear_lowest." The digit surface should be at the bottom, and it should fit snugly onto the mounting-hub/motor-shaft.

  • Cut a 5/32" brass tube such that it can rest on top of the motor shaft and also reach the top of the reed-switch holder.

  • Insert counter_gear_bottom into counter_gear_top. Rest it on top of counter_gear_lowest such that the middle holes are aligned. 20-tooth gear should be on the bottom.

  • Rest counter_gear_highest on top such that the 20-tooth gear is on the bottom.

  • Insert the brass tube you cut in step 8 so that it holds all 3 digit wheels in place, but they can all move independently of one another.

  • Cut another short segment of 5/32" brass rod so that it fits in the whole length of the reed switch holder. Insert the two 8-tooth partial gears such that they rest on top of the 'digit' layer and sit between the gears. Insert the rod to hold them in place.

  • Your counter should be complete! All three reed switches should trip when the counter reads "0-0-0," and the circuit will complete.

module foot()
{

}

{

{

rotate([0,0,90])translate([0,-3 + 0.65,-2 1.5]) cube([25, 6, 7 1.5]);
}

translate([0,0,5 * 1.5])meFoot();

translate([0,0,-10.5])cube([60,60,10], center = true);

};

description.text:
This ball was inspired by the scientific buckyball. The Buckyball has a very appealing structure so I decided to create an artistic representation of that. However, it is not an attempt to replicate the actual Buckyball structure. It actually has little resemblance to that structure in the end but the name stuck.

For some reason Thingiverse will not let me upload the STL file (no matter how I process it - I have tried to export from all kinds of different programs) so I have uploaded the gcode file, Makerbot Thing file and Simplify 3D file.

Ball Gluing

After printing two of these models you can use clear epoxy to glue them together. At first I thought a clamp would be the way to align the halves but after experimentation, I found it best just to manually align the shapes and then let it setup - no clamp necessary; the clamp seemed to skew the alignment because of the slick surface of the faces.

Preparations

You'll need 4x M4 nuts, 4x M4 x 20mm (or 24mm), a 5mm drill for the holes and of course the tool mount.

Drill your holes as with the dimensions described on Vicious1's assembly guide here:
http://www.vicious1.com/assembly/conduit-rails-tubes-pipes/

author: H256

title: TOM build platform cable management system

description.text:
This thing is the end result of an ongoing project to manage the wires coming off the ThingOMatic Heated Build Platform.  I needed to print objects which were near the maximum size of the TOM build envelope, and found that when printing at the corners of the platform the cable would frequently become pinched between the build platform or Y stage and the TOM enclosure, stalling the servos and ruining the print.  I also didn't like how the cables would rub against the Y stage smooth rods and pully sometimes, and wanted to do something about a strain relief for the HBP connector.
This Thing is the result, a system of parts which completely encloses the cable and forces it to move in a predictable path that stays out of the way of the build platform and Y stage, and also acts as some degree of a strain relief for the build platform and Y axis endstop connectors.  With this Thing my TOM can print objects filling the entire print volume reliably.
The chain link is anchored in three spots.  The X stage end anchors to the wooden rib on the right side of the build platform.  This will require a small hole to be drilled for a bolt to hold this piece in place.  A zip-tie is used here to secure the HBP cable.
The centerpoint piece attaches to the right side of the Y stage.  This requires removing one of the rod endcap plates and attaching the printed part in its place.  This is the most annoying part of the installation as you have to partially dissassemble the end of the Y stage to get this piece in place.
The baseplate anchor is the easiest to install, it just snap-fits into the square hole in the corner of the clear plastic plate.
The cable links snap together, and can be installed after you have the anchor pieces in place.  I use 9 links between the build platform and the midpoint anchor, and 10 between the midpoint and the baseplate anchor, but you may find different numbers work better for you depending on how long your cables are.  Each chain link has slots where you can zip-tie the wires in place if you desire, although I haven't found that to be necessary.  These chain links may also be useful by themselves in other applications where you need to control the movement of a moving cable bundle.
This Thing can be attached to an existing TOM without having to disconnect any cables in the process.

Print out one baseplate anchor, one midpoint anchor, one X stage anchor, and five of the four chain link piece (for 20 links in total).
Clean up the parts.  File out the holes in the chains and the sliding surfaces until the chains flex smoothly when snapped together.
Press a single M3 hex nut into the slot in the base of the X stage anchor.  Make sure it lines up with the hole through this piece.
Put the X stage anchor in place on the rib and mark the hole location.  Remove the anchor and drill a small hole in that spot.  Put the X stage anchor back in place and use a singe M3x16 machine screw to hold it in place.  Use a zip-tie to anchor the HBP cable to this piece.
Take apart the right side of the Y platform, and remove the endcap from the front rod.  Tuck the HBP cable into the groove in the centerpoint anchor, then attach the centerpoint anchor in place of the smooth rod endcap you removed.  Reassemble the right side of the Y platform.  Optionally, zip-tie the HBP cable and the Y axis endstop cable to the centerpoint anchor, using the two slots provided.
Snap together 9 links of chain between the X stage anchor and the centerpoint anchor.  Note that the chain link closest to the centerpoint anchor has to be installed in the opposite direction from the others in order for the cable to be able to make the 90 degree turn.
Place the baseplate anchor around the cable coming off the Y stage.  Place a chain link on the other side of the cable, and then snap them together so that the cable is going through the anchor and the chain.  Press the anchor down into the hole in the base plate as far as it will go, then tilt it towards the front of the machine and then move it as far forward as it will go.  See photo for what it should look like.
Snap chain links onto the cable as needed, using 9 or so in total, with the last one also snapped onto the centerpoint anchor.
Now with the steppers unpowered, move the X and Y axis back and forth between their travel limits, and make sure the cable chains do not snag or rub on anything at any point during their travel.  You may need to adjust things a bit until it all moves smoothly.

description.text:
DIY Cyborg Data Gloves

Project Grip is a minimalist data glove designed to control wearable computers. Its ring-like configuration exposes the fingers and palm, and its low friction maximizes maneuverability.

Requires Flexpoint polyimide-coated sensors. Will not work with Spectra flex sensors.

Unlike conventional data gloves, your Project Grip is intended for everyday wear. It measures a single joint per finger, which is unsuitable for full-immersion VR but more than enough to control a Google Glass, Moverio, Raspberry Pi, or other HUD computer. The low profile and minimal friction make your Project Grip comfortable enough to wear all day. If you break a ring, simply print another.

What you get

This model includes four sets of finger sensor carrier rings, one for each finger. The rings are worn on the first and second joint and hold a polyimide-coated Flexpoint flex sensor with its factory-installed socket.

You must use a polyimide Flexpoint sensor. The rough 3D-printed surface will scrape Spectra flex sensors, polyester-coated sensors, and uncoated sensors to destruction.

Measuring the sensors

You are expected to design and build your own wearable device to measure and act on the sensors. The Flexpoint sensors are exceptionally repeatable and can be read with a simple resistor divider and modern ADC.

No thumb?

The thumb was intentionally excluded. Wearing this sensor on the thumb would cover the thumb tip and unnecessarily restrict manual dexterity.

FAQ

  • There are too many parameters! Print a set, test fit, and then adjust anything that's uncomfortable or loose.
  • What flex sensor can I use? You can use a Flexpoint polyimide (Kapton) flex sensor. Make sure it comes with the blue plastic socket. You can size your Project Grip to fit the 1", 2", or 3" sensor. You can buy these sensors directly from Flexpoint.
  • Can I use a Spectra flex sensor? No. You must use a Flexpoint sensor. Spectra flex sensors suck anyways.
  • But I can only get Spectra sensors on Adafruit/Sparkfun/The People's Republic of Yakoslevonia! Life sucks. Wear a hat.
  • Why only one sensor per finger? It's all you need to pick up common gestures like pointing. More sensors would make the glove clunkier.
  • Why no thumb? One of the thumb rings would need to cover the thumb tip, basically making the finger useless. It's also very obstructive. You can often infer thumb position from the other fingers.
  • Will these connect to my phone/brain/Google Glass/drone? Yes. You will need to build the electronics yourself.
  • Will you build those electronics for me? Yes. My base rate is $150 per hour. It'll take about 50 hours to make your electronics.
  • But I want to use this right now! Welcome to the bleeding edge, broski.
  • What are you connecting yours to? An Epson Moverio. I'll share more info when that's done.
  • Could I use these to control a video game or a sequencer? Your life will likely end within 40 years. Please use your remaining time more productively.
  • Is this a total ripoff of the Gest? Yes. Also the P5 Glove.
  • Why do you have tiny little baby fingers? I didn't drink my milk when I was a kid.
  • How does this compare to the Power Glove? Far more accurate, and far less bad.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

Irrelevant

20%

Notes:

Print with three shells for increased strength.

To further increase strength, ensure that the rings are parallel with the build plate. This prevents layer boundaries from adding weak points to the ring.

The model tolerates low layer heights well. Use the thickest possible layers to print models for test fits. Print your final set at high resolution to minimize uncomfortable rough spots.

The customizable script will generate each finger individually. Don't waste time printing unnecessary fingers!

After a few failed prints (as is normal with this machine) you will probably notice that that hot filament will bork your existing insulation pretty quickly. It is some sore of cotton fiber wrapped in what appears to be kapton tape. This just wont do. For me I noticed that the cotton fibers absorbed a considerable amount of PLA over the hours. It was pretty nasty. So I came up with this solution to not only fix the problem but prevent it all together.  
Since this mod, I have noticed that my machine heats up noticeably faster and sees much less heat pollution beneath the build platform. The area directly beneath the nozzle sits about 15C cooler as confirmed by a laser thermometer whereas the surface of the insulation sits almost 35C cooler. There are no immediate visible changes in print quality, however this equation should, in theory, aid with bridging and increase the efficiency of your current filament fan.  
Thanks for reading!

Sugru claims to be resistant to "+180C". This was enough for me to give it a try and it works quite well.  
I disassembled the extruder and pulled the existing insulation off of the heat block. I then cleaned the entire assembly ans applied a ~1.5mm layer of Sugru around being sure to leave room to swap out any parts such as the nozzle in the future. It is important to knead the Sugru extremely thoroughly before applying it to release any air bubbles. Air bubbles will expand and destroy your insulation. I let it cure for 36 hours to ensure that it was on for good. Finally, the extruder is reassembled and the build plate is re-leveled and you're off!

comments.text:
FYI it's not cotton, it's a ceramic fiber tape. Cotton would probably just burn up.
Also, Sugru's website says it's only resistant to 180ºC, is its failure mode at 230ºC (or higher!) dangerous?

author: wolfi5589

title: Leapfrog Creatr (Mod) for E3D Titan - Dual Carriage (Horizontal 60mm LM8UU Carriage)

description.text:
Youtube of Working Carriage
https://youtu.be/ZQKzDLqYL30

  • Background -- Existing Carriage with Direct Drive (1:1) has a hard time with tougher filaments, like PETG / Carbon or Nylon / Carbon, and Direct Drive directly from stepper motor has "Step Lines" on extruded filament, making final part "wavy" on surface of the part. Not only that, Direct extrusion straight from the motor seems underpowered on Nema 17s, as most filament that should easily go through, seems to jam up, however it is the extruder that fails to push and "clicks" at the motor. Even at 1/32 microstepping, extruder need further micronic steps to do most extrusion moves. Geared Extruder is usually required for tougher filaments, reliability, smooth extrusion, and power. E3D Titan, is readily available on market, and gives 3:1 ratio on Stepper Motor, providing 3 times the power, smooths filament as it extrudes. Keeping with "Direct Drive" Extrusion (Not Bowden), this Carriage fits the bill making it easy to get reliability with extrusion.
  • Similar Style to Existing Carriage for Leapfrog Creatr (Dual Head) - Tabbed Lock-in Groove and Modular Design, however modified Carriage to fit E3D Titan (Geared) Extruder, which has 11.1mm offset from motor center (requiring slightly larger carriage), Currently E3D's Titan does not has a "mirrored" version. Titan Extruder fits Side by Side in this arrangement.
  • No additional parts required, it has locking tabs that secure the carriage once in place once assembled, and secures the LM8UU Bearings.
  • Also included fan mounting underneath the motors to cool the e3d hotend.
  • All parts made in 4mm "plates". Lock in Tabs on Rear help hold the Motor Up.
  • 2x Locking Pipes for LM8UU to keep in holes at proper distances. (May be overkill if there's already a snug fit, but this will ensure that Bearings will not come out of place.)

You will need:

  • 4x new LM8UU 8mm Bearings, as old bearings have been tacked to old Carriage
    (Readily available on Ebay.) 8mm ID, 15mm OD x 24mm Hgt.
    2x E3D Titan Universal Extruder

Print Job Requires:

  • 1/ea - Motor Plate, Front Fan Plate, Base Plate
  • 2/ea - Side Plates, Locking Tabs, and Locking Pipe for LM8UU Bearing

Threading --

  • Fan Plate
    M4x0.7 Thread - 4 Holes for Belt Driven Tabs, 8x for 40mm fans (if holes are not large enough for through hole) -- Backside for Belt Tab Holes, you can put a M4x0.7 Jam Nut, spot provided to jam it in, provides additional support if threading is too difficult on Plastic.
  • Motor Plate
    M3x0.5 Thread - 2 Holes for Drag Chain / Wire Carriage
    (Note -- Drag Chain / Wire Carriage should probably be screwed in on backside (above 2nd motor), facing left.)
  • Base Plate
    M4x0.7 Thread (Optional 2 holes for underside fan, 10 mm apart, centered between the 2 hotends - apx 54 mm apart.)

( Also Included Option for Filament Guide - Original Plates had Filament Guide Supported on top with M6 thread, option with Fan Plate / Motor Plate included... Thread the holes with M6x1.0 through holes, connects Fan Plate with Motor Plate on top for additional rigidity. )

Note: To lock in Front Tab requires the fans to be raised, leave middle top screws in only, and swing both up to lock in Front Tab. Swing back down upon installing Front Tab.

Software Instructions (Arduino Config settings)

  • Reverse Extruder Direction, side by side config, both should be the same direction, mine is set to 'false' on both E0 and E1.
  • Calibrate / Change # of Steps /Unit. For 1/32 Microstepping, I use value of 834.35 per unit (mm). (Or apx 3 times previous amount.)
  • (Offsets) Extruder 2 should have an offset on X Axis of 54mm from Extruder 1, either set in Ariduino Config file, or in Software as Tool 2 Offset.
  • Calibrate Z Axis to new depth (may be slightly lower), ensure that you do not run the Z Axis into the Carriage.

Printer Brand:

Leapfrog

Printer:

Creatr

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

100%

Notes:

All dimensions are exact fit, I use a little bit of Dimensional Adjustment, -0.20 for items to fit snug in each others slot without having to file or shave a bit off each slot. # of Outlines / Solid Layers: I use 4 for Top / Bottom / Outline to give a solid outline.
Currently using ABS as it is the only thing that will print with 1:1 Direct Drive Extruder.
PLA makes for rigid 4mm plates as well.
Also had to upgrade Heatbed to AC 110V on SSR to get heatbed to get up to 110C. Factory had it on 24V which could only reach 60C in 40 minutes. Heatbed is massive 300x350mm, 7ohm across leads, on SSR relay, 4 minutes to 110C, all controlled through PID through software, on same 24V line, to send "signal" rather than power (current) to SSR for transferring 110V AC power to heatbed, recommend to run as PID, rather than Bang Bang (full on, then full off switching). Limited Max Power to 64 in Arduino Configuration.h file. Ask for settings, I will tell you PID values, or run Autotune.

author: Silencebreaker

description.text:
Alright, I was bored the other day and decided to make the longboard I just purchased into an electric board. (Too lazy to pump all the time) A couple hours later here's what I have. The designs are pretty crude but they work.

Parts:
Longboard
-Yoacher 41 inch drop deck board (The one i have)

Brushless motor
-Hobbyking 5055 400kv motor

80+ amp speed controller
-Turnigy 85A

Belt
-55 teeth 110XL synchronous belt

Pinion
1.5mm Pitch 10 Teeth 6mm Bore Motor Part Timing Belt Pulley Sprocket

2ch R/C car radio and reciever
-quanum 3ch

Your choice of battery (3s runs perfect I'd say around 10-15 mph 6s for dangerous speeds)

  • 4000mah+ 20c+

That's pretty much it I printed the parts at 0.2mm layers at 100% infill on my prusia i3. Epoxy the wheel pulley onto the wheel and its good. Make sure its centered to avoid vibrations.
Bracket is friction fit so hammer it good in there.
Works well and cheap.

Oh yeah, you're going to need some extra spacers for the wheel if you cant hammer the bracket in enough. 1-2mm distance from the wheel gear is good. I have 3 spacers or washers on my wheel.
Battery tray is a friction fit for the battery as well for a Multistar 5200mah pack 23x50x145mm

This is what worked for me, do it at your own risk.

Update 6/9/16

Got a new rc car esc (120A FVT)which has better acceleration and braking curve. (So much better!)

drilled and added grub screw to the motor mount to axle to prevent it sliding to the wheel gear under hard vibrations.

printed parts in new color and just got red wheels. Runs like a dream!

Update 6/14/16

Phew, found an awesome upload by droftarts (Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles)
(awesome openscad file)
Used his scad file to create a wheel gear that fits the belt PERFECTLY. 37 teeth.
less area to epoxy onto the wheel but its enough. (Wait atleast 24 hours for it to cure)

title: MK7 safety cutoff and feed tube mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mounting plate for the MK7 safety cutoff board and a 1/4 inch feeder tube.
I created this because on a Cupcake, there's no good place to put the safety cutoff board, so I needed somewhere to mount it, and I use a feeder tube (so that the filament stays in a sealed box with dessicant). The feeder tube wouldn't stay straight, so I needed a way to hold it up.
I will be posting an updated version of this with more airflow channels and an additional fan, since my extruder motor gets SUPER hot...

1) Remove extruder and safety cutoff board from bot
2) Remove fan from extruder
3) Bolt fan to this part
4) Re-assemble extruder
5) Press an M3 nut into each slot on the top of the part (may take some coaxing)
6) Bolt the safety cutoff board to the side of the part using the nuts you just pressed into place
7) Re-attach the extruder to the bot
8) feed filament through your 1/4 inch feed tube
9) feed some filament into the extruder while manually running the motor (through RepG) until the drive gear grabs it
10) press the end of the feed tube down into this part
11) Heat up the bot and run a test extrusion to make sure everything works
12) ???
13) sorry, don't profit without getting my permission first, but feel free to share!

Notes:

Remixed to use less filament (and still be fit for purpose)

For years I have seen people struggle with getting parts to fit together well. There did not seem to be a good method of finding the correct tolerance between parts (gap in the model).

I created six different testers and each one has a different range of offsets. All units are in millimeters. Typically I find that if your working with two 3d printed parts there needs to be a offset of .25mm on one of the parts (or you can get fancy and add half to both parts). Similarly if you are working with one 3d printed part and one non 3d printed part (a metal rod, screw, etc) you need a offset of about .13mm. These are just ballparks ideas of where to start and each machine, slicer settings, and nozzle diameter will give different results.

(Select tester size you want + 5mm Rod + 5mm Square Rod)

note:

  • on some machines the offset needed in one direction (x) may not be the same as the offset needed in the other direction (Y) due to low quality build parts.
  • Would not recommend printing the testers with a brim. It is ok to do on the rods.

description.text: With dual extruders on a ToM, there isn't much space for some of the other nice cooling fan shrouds like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15430 So, this thing holds a 60mm wide fan out front and directs the air flow down under the nozzles pretty effectively. I also threw in an awesome-tastic r.Maker face. :) It works great, however I don't like how it obscures the view of the nozzles while it's printing. So I might re-design it so the fan is vertical instead... but then I might lose that sweet r.Maker head... Optionally, you could just use the r.Maker head without the fan to add some style to your MakerBot and keep your fingers from hitting the extruder fans. Here's a before and after picture of how a cooling fan can improve print quality (especially with PLA): http://www.flickr.com/photos/tbuser/6709804997/

You'll need 6 x M3 bolts about 25mm long and 6 M3 nuts and a 60mm wide fan.
The whole thing attaches to the Z stage just by sliding under the extruder mounting plate between the metal plate and the wooden z stage.  It fits just tight enough to keep it secure without needing any screws.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: I wanted to make something any school could, and would use. This is a simple, sliding pie graph that shows the fraction as well as the amount the fraction takes up. This allows the user to understand fractions and how much space the fraction will ultimately take up. I would suggest printing the two disks a different color, but it is not necessary. The two different colors will allow you to see the contrast of the two disks much better. I designed this for the #MakerEdChallenge #MathProject #Tinkercad

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.10 or .20

Infill:

100% Preffered

Notes:

Either PLA or Abs can be used, though PLA would most likely have a better outcome. The disks are very thin so 100% infill will increase the strength greatly.

How I Made This

I used Tinkercad.com to design this. I used basic shapes and holes to make the model as simple as possible and easy to use, but still functionable.

Project: Fractions Made Easy

Project: Fractions Made Easy!
Objectives: Students will be able to understand fraction and incorporate the actual amount of space the fraction takes up.
Audiences: The audience for this project is geared towards younger grades such as FIrst Grade through Fifth Grade, but it can be used for any age or grade.
Preparation: The student will need to know what a fraction is to understand the model. Although this will help to understand fractions, one with little experience may have trouble with this.
Steps:

  1. Start by printing the four files, there is no order.
  2. Take the two disks, the one with the fractions on the outer edge on bottom, and put the pin in the middle to connect them.
  3. Spread the split in the top disk with the left side flap up and the right side down.
  4. Place the left side flap of the bottom disk between the opening and pull it through so that you can see it now.
  5. Push the pins together tight so that your project will not come apart.
  6. GO LEARN FRACTIONS!
    Results: The student should now have a handheld device that can be taken relatively anywhere, and can be used in school and outside of school. They can now learn fractions without having to draw or assemble a confusing fraction model.
    MakerEdChallenge #MathProject #Tinkercad #MakerEdChallenge2

Project Overview

Fractions Made Easy is a simple but effective way for anyone to learn fractions. It has a simple design so that just about anyone who uses it will understand it. You can expect about an hours worth of printing for a highly detailed model.

title: Teach your child to count from 11-20 with this crazy jigsaw.

description.text:
So I had a puzzle for our 2 year old son with numbers 1 to 10 on it. Since he's got the hang of counting to 10, I thought I'd make an 11 to 20 puzzle. It's designed to fit into a box which is 13cm x 60cm but it will work without one.

I've put a regular geometric shape and an unusual object on each tile. Please be aware these are not CE marked toys etc... so please supervise small children.

There are 1mm clearances between the pieces and puzzle cuts so they fit together really easily and will print without interference on pretty much any 3D printer.

Notes:

Print whatever settings you feel work for you.

Using tinkercad public file is here: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kdioeGXeG1Q-mega-puzzle-count-from-11-to-20/edit
If you want to alter it.

comments.text: Thank you so much for the effort you put into this and sharing it with us, I am going to print one for my daughters pre-school, we will donate it to pay it forward :)

comments.text: You're welcome. If I re-did it, I'd probably change some of the shapes as some don't print well, or snap off when under toddler-attack. It would be nice as well to pause print and change filament for a contrasting colour for the numbers.

title: SSD Mount 2.5 to 3.5 Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After wandering the net looking for a SSD mount, we decided to make our own. We needed something that was quick to print, cheap and easy to use. This is a single side, you will need to print two. The reason we created only one side was to make it super easy to use, you don't need to match a set, just grab two and you're on your way.

This will convert a 2.5 SSD drive to a 3.5 (standard HD) size to be used wherever you use a HD.

**7-7-2016 Updated the file to be more symmetrical. Added a file that has a pair nested somewhat to facilitate easier printing. Also, I uploaded all the different file versions I can from Fusion 360 which is what I used to create this.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Folger Prusa i3

No

title: Vernier Caliper Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a basic clamp that holds your vernier caliper on your 8mm rods for a very accurate calibration of steps/mm. 16x5mm caliper opening. 25x25x23 mm

Find the best way to have the movement of the axis collapse the caliper, Zero it in the extended position, then drive the axis 50mm and read.

Use the calibration procedure here:

http://reprap.org/wiki/Triffid_Hunter's_Calibration_Guide#XY_steps

For the X and Y, I found it easiest to have the hole-gage on the carriage, for Z the head rested on the X/Z bearing holder.

Please ask any questions, this is my first uploaded thing.

Made in CREO Parametric, I can upload the source file in any format that CREO will do, just ask.

title: X-Wing Miniatures - Toolbox Bin for Imperial Damage Decks

description.text:
This is a Large sized bin to hold X-Wing Miniatures Game Damage Decks.

I wanted a way to split up as well as store my decks but still have them accessible for play.

This one holds Fore/Aft decks for both the Raider and the Assault Carrier, as well as the Base damage deck from both the Original core set and The Force Awakens core set.

Printer:

Wanhao Di3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Depending on what colour this is printed in, you may need to accent the text somehow.

I've included the Sketchup file if you prefer reverse the text to make it protrude rather than be inset.

title: Greatsword Knights (Wargaming Minis)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a derivative of "World of Warcraft - Nightelf Death Knight" by mandun in the sketchup warehouse. http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=a71ca1aada5552e6b480d8a0fa501a4b&prevstart=0 This is the first grunt unit I put together for my all printed warmachine army. I modified him for printing including:
  • Removed unprintable details (cloak/ears/etc)
  • Redrew the sword. I made it cartoonish intentionally.
  • Reposed for some variety in the unit.
  • Some modification for printing. He has clown feet now so he stands up better.
    • I'll be playing this unit as proxies for stormblades. Note: Warmachine and the related terms are property of privateer press. This model is not intended to actually look like or be the model they provide but is simply my proxy for it.
The 4 poses are only slightly different.  I added additional changes by hand with a blow torch.  If you reshape them by hand be careful since the shoulders are largely hollow.

comments.text:
I was aware that these are wow models but I didn
Ã¢Â€Â™t know that they were direct exports. I wasnÃ¢Â€Â™t labeling them as such (other than pointing to my source) or naming them what I would be playing them as since I was trying to avoid problems like the guy with the war hammer models had. I doubt blizzard will have a problem with these as they are
non-commercial releases and donÃ¢Â€Â™t compete with anything they sell. In any case I got these from the sketchup warehouse where I am permitted to make derivatives and redistribute and which is itself a respectable source. Unless I hear otherwise IÃ¢Â€Â™ll be assuming that the original poster there had
permission to add these models.

comments.text: Blizzard is much more relaxed with uses of their property then Games workshop. For example the Starcraft 2 mod called "World of Starcraft" only had to change their name, so Blizzard could protect that name. They still could continue development. And they allow many fan made movies that clearly use all kinds of hacks to achieve results impossible in normal WoW.

comments.text: These were printed on my Prusa Mendel.  It has the somewhat standard upgrades of linear bearings and gt2 belts.  I'm using a standard .5mm nozzle and printing at 190C in PLA on blue tape.  There is some active cooling for these prints.  I have a fan positioned so it blows primarily over my electronics but also catches the print.

comments.text: I do not know what was the "terrible results" but for such small and tall prints on my UM I decrease flow by 10-15% comparing to normal printing based on volumetric calculations. And it works well.

This vase is a concept design. It is not meant to be printed. It can be SLS printed without issue. It can be FDM printed but it will not turn out very pretty.

A vase inside of another vase. It is actually one vase, the interior is hollow. The disks appear bigger than they really are. They are the same thickness as the gaps (11.125 mm).

7 in tall (17.78 cm) so scale down to desired size. Use supports.

The first picture is the slimmer version. The second is the wider version. I included both stl files.

title: KühlCase - A RAMPS Cable Management and Cooler Case (Hictop Prusa i3)

description.text: This design utilizes a "grip bar" to ensure the wires do not move and work themselves out of the RAMPS board (this one is the Hictop AS1552 board, but it might work with yours as well).

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 Aluminium

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

What you need:

19x 3M 12mm Bolts

Optional Fan Speed Control:

The fan here does not require full power, but when it runs at full power it can get loud. So if you add approximately 150-50ohms of resistance for my fan (12v 0.1amps) to drop the voltage to 5-9v depending on what you want.

BE CAREFUL THOUGH!!!
Most common place resistors only have a 0.25 Watt rating so you and you will need 0.5-1 Watt-rated resistance so, for example, if you want 100 Ohms use two 200 Ohm resistors in parallel to get 100 Ohms total split across two 0.25 Watt (0.5 Watt total) rated resistors.

Use this site to do the calculations for you. http://www.blackfiveservices.co.uk/fanspeedcalc.php?Voltage=12&Current=0.1&Target=6

description.text:
Drone Racing Mod for the Mobius Action Camera

The "MoPro" Mod takes the lens from the side of the camera and moves it to the front like a GoPro style action cam.

New features include:
Lens swap to the front of the camera
Flatted out the camera bottom to provide more stability when mounted
Zip-tie loop to easily secure the camera and eliminate risk of camera being ejected from aircraft

To make the mod work you will need to purchase an upgraded Lens ribbon cable (link provided below) in order to twist the lens into its new position.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Mobius-Actioncam-1080P-2-5-CM-26-Pin-Lens-Extension-Cable-/291415457724?hash=item43d9b6ffbc:g:l4oAAOSw7aBVEkLx

I printed this in PLA and other filament should work just as well.

Some filing around the usb port maybe be necessary to make the usb fit... I also filed the edges of the board itself slightly to fit into the new casing and line up all the screw holes.

All of the existing screws that you will take out of the Mobius will be needed to secure the electronics back into this Modded case.

Once you have everything packed nice and neat in the case an opening in the rear of the case allows you to apply some hot glue to the back of the camera and the case to secure the camera in place.

description.text: A small end-table for milling out of 1/2" plywood. The parts can all be cut from a single quarter panel of plywood (2'x4') with a bit of room to spare. The tolerances are a bit tight so you may need to file the slots a little to get everything to fit. Mine is friction fit; it's malleted together without glue.

The only non-obvious bits are the pockets in the top of the table that the tabs at the top of the legs sit in. They should be about 0.32-0.35" deep. I also ran a 90 degree V-bit at a depth of 0.24" around the outer perimeter of the table top to create a decorative bevel on the bottom (the tabletop being milled upside-down). I used a 1/4" downcut end mill; be sure to add the appropriate fillets for your tool before you cut (or be prepared to file/cut those inner slot corners square by hand).

description.text:
this is a toy a i made earlier in the year it is mechanical and fun to play around with. this was made in auto-desk inventor so i could see the mechanics working. attached in the download is the STL file for each part, the IPT file for the finished piece and the STL for the final piece. this was very fun to make and hopefully u enjoy playing with it.

parts required for full piece
-4x dips
-1x wall right
-1x wall left
-1x floor
-1x wall back
-1x roof
-1x handle
-1x boat back
-1x boat back middle
-1x boat front middle
-1x boat front
-1x waves (not required just for fun)

how i designed this

it all started as a school project that i put my own spin on and created this toy/simulation.

project

ROUGH TIDES MECHANICAL TOY

OVERVIEW & BACKGROUND- you will learn the basic skill of moving multiple parts at once using constraints in a CAG software.

OBJECTIVES- students will learn: how to move multiple parts at once using constraints in CAG software, how to create parts from scratch while still using the same mechanism, how to research what is popular on the market to create a popular toy.

AUDIENCE- the skill level would be the Scottish grade (SQA) of national 5 as a requirement however with some practice anyone can do it.

SUBJECTS- relevant subjects would include graphics communication and maybe design manufacture.

SKILLS LEARNED-this project allows pupils to experience something new in the graphics communications higher (SQA qualification) course this shall allow pupils to begin the year with something exciting. as a pupil who has sat the course myself it has come more as an experience to what i wish to do today.

LESSON/ACTIVITY- to complete the project each pupil must has all there parts (picture shown below) to create the toy. they must also assemble and create a step by step guide to creating their toy.

DURATION- this part of the course can take anything from 1 month to 4 therefore making it quite a bulky part of the course.

PREPARATION- pupils show have know how to use a CAG software to national 5 level (SQA grade) to be able to sit the course however pupils in there 5th and 6th year have a chance to "crash" the course therefore meaning they don't need the grades required as long as the teacher allows it.

RUBRIC AND ASSESSMENT- each pupil must have created a mechanical toy that is unique. if they succeed this the teacher marks it if over 50% thy are allowed to sit the final exam at the end of the year if not they fail the course.however some exceptions can be made if the teacher knows the pupil has the potential to do well in the subject.

HANDOUTS AND ASSETS- n/a

This is a fully functional hand-cranked model of the throated (also known as globoid) worm drive. To put it together, you will also need 10 metric countersunk Phillips-head screws M3x12 and 2 metric nuts M3. Those can be purchased cheaply on eBay.

If you are curious how to model a throated worm drive, we have a video tutorial at www.otvinta.com.

We recommend that the two halves of the worm shaft be printed with a raft for better coupling. The raft and remaining residue should be removed with sand paper.

If printed properly, the crankhandle's grip should rotate freely around the handle.

File parts clamp1.stl and clamp2.stl in the archive are identical. There are two versions of the stand: with the logo (stand.stl) and without (stand_nologo.stl). Print one or the other.

description.text:
Just a quick design I threw together to protect a recent eBay Purchase - a "AD584 4-Channel 2.5V/5V/7.5V/10V High Precision Voltage Reference Module". Unlike another design here on thingiverse, was the smaller square one, and there didn't seem to be any designs round for it.

The design I used seemed a bit too tight - didn't need to use screws to hold it in, the board needed a minor filing, and the print needed some minor trimming. So I resized it and made 1mm bigger, so that should hopefully make it more of a drop in fit if that is your preference, or you can use the original model ;)

Printer:

Flux Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Ran the print at medium quality, as it didn't need to be a perfect print.

Basically just measured the module up, and created a design in tinkercad. I wanted the bottom of the board completely protected, and the top half clear so as to not block access to the connectors. The built-in standoffs are there to ensure the protruding solder joints are not stressed. As my first model was a tight fit, I didn't need to use screws to hold it in place.

If you do a search on TinkerCad's website you should be able to find these designs there.

title: Pole to Screw hole insert adapter (in this case attaching lights to pole)

description.text:
Video showing the application of the thing(s).
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-62275D5DJ0 I really don't know what to call this. It's essentially a snap on adapter that attaches to a pole, and on the back there is a object similiar to a screw that slides into objects designed to hang by screws. As in you can hang stuff off of a pole if it has the slide on screw slots on the back. The basic design here is for fitting to a floor lamp, and the "screw" like pertrusion on the back slides into florescent light fixtures. I attached 4 of them to the lamp post 2 for each of the lamps. The purpose of this to create a portable 360 degree UV-C lamp which I could move room to room, and was powerful enough to get the job done. UV-C lights can be bought on amazon, the ballasts are from wal-mart as well as the lamp. UV-c light kills bacteria, virus, and kills fleas and disrupts the eggs of the fleas from hatching. NOTE UV-C is harmful to humans and animals,so don't use an UV-C lamp without protection, or leave the room while it is on. I'm using a 30 minute timer and just leaving the room while it is running. I'm using this to try to eliminate fleas, as it seems nothing I try can completely eliminate them, So I made this. I will upload pictures, so you can see what I mean shortly, and I will have a video of it. OH, I had to point the "Screw" is on the bottom, because despite my best effort it would not print at this particular sizing successfully with it in the middle, and the model oriented with the pipe section face down, though it will if the pipe was larger, as then the layer changes are not so abrupt when printing the circle. There are Tapered screws in the sketchup file that could be used instead, if your application allowed for middle mounting of the "fake" screw.

I uploaded the Sketchup file and the STl file, you should be able to adjust the sketchup file to fit your particular pole/lamp, and you can adjust the size of the plastic screw "imitation" located on the back to fit the slot of the device you want to place on it. 
There are Sketchup to STL plugins on the internet. 
The best method of adjust is to probably remove the screw "imitation" from the back, then readjust the primary slot, then adjust the screw "imitation" then place that back into the primary design. There really is no other way to do it, considering both those variables need to match your particular application. 
I did find the default width matches other common items though like my curtain rods, so you may get lucky, though the fake "screw" on the back would need adjust to fit my speakers. 
Enough rambling... HEHE.

description.text: Battery cover for the Tandy 100. It's a tight fit because it was designed to print in PLA, and I wanted to make sure that there was a decent amount of plastic at all of the stress points so that it won't break apart under normal use. If you don't mind that, you can print a replacement battery door yourself.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Architect

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10%, unless your printer tries to infill the catches, which should be more like 100% for structural integrity. Try 10 and see if it works; the catches are probably too small to be infilled anywhere.

Notes:

I'm actually not sure about the rafts. I used the "skirt" option in Slic3r, which I'm trying out at the moment, and that worked fine. If it peels up around the edges, add rafts. Sufficient supports are built-in.
Nothing serious. Just be very careful triming the supports out, the rear catches are still a bit fragile and can be pried apart from the door if you've got a big enough knife.

Took a bunch of measurements of an actual battery door from another unit, threw them at OpenSCAD, and got a quick mock-up. After that it was just a matter of measuring actual fit and rigidity of the part, and adding plastic until the clips held up when the part was snapped on and off of the system.

title: Flysky / Turnigy i6 Transmitter FPV Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my solution to pair a Flysky i6 transmitter with an Eachine FPV monitor, though it should work with other displays that use the same rear screw-to-square-nut mounting method. I wanted it to be solid but also removable to make transport easy and hoped to avoid any additional adhesives/cable ties. After rather a few iterations, this is the version that I have found best meets those goals.

Printed using Bilby 3D PLA at 10% infill on a Flashforge Dreamer it is quite solid. Tolerances are very tight to ensure pieces snap together and stay together so results may vary on other printers and materials.

Additional materials you will need are just a screw, square nut and possibly a washer for mounting the FPV monitor (Bolt approx 12mm deep with diameter to match your screen mount (mounting holes are 6mm diameter)).

This was my first design using Onshape. Loving it so far, can't recommend it highly enough.

Would love to hear about your experience with this design, please get it touch if you have any questions or feedback.

Happy flying!

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

10%

Notes:

PLA works fine so far. No other materials tested.

description.text:
I wanted to design a business card which stood-out. So I measured the dimensions of a credit card, modelled it up in FreeCAD, and put my name/email on it. It turned out pretty awesome... I figure someone else may like this idea, so I wrote a routine up in OpenSCAD and uploaded it here! Technically you can write whatever 3 lines you wish. It's fully adjustable on font size + placement.

It's a novel business card which makes a good nerdy impression.

Printer:

BraggBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

<= 0.3

Infill:

100%

Before OpenSCAD I used FreeCAD

I usually design things in CAD because it's easier. Once the design is done, it can then be translated over to OpenSCAD. FreeCAD is fairly familiar because I took mechanical drawing (by hand) and CAD for a couple quarters in High School. OpenSCAD is fairly familiar because I took a couple years of C++ in High School. So, with just High School education, you should have sufficient knowledge to replicate this from scratch if desired.

FreeCAD

Overview & Background

Print a business card to give yourself a competitive edge amongst other young professionals/students.

Objectives

Minimally you'll learn how to 3D print. Additionally, you could learn:
(1) How to use a customizer
(2) How to use OpenSCAD (copy the code here and edit)
(3) How to edit g-code (more on this later)

Audiences

Anyone old enough to use a 3D printer

Subjects

If you plan to edit the OpenSCAD:

  • Computer Science (preferably C)
  • Geometry

If you plan on using this as inspiration and going to FreeCAD:

  • Mechanical Drawing
  • Computer Aided Drafting
  • Geometry
Skills Learned (Standards)

Synthesis of aforementioned subjects (geometry, CAD, computer science).

Lesson/Activity

Run the customizer to generate the STL. Slice the STL. Edit the g-code so that you can replace your filament (if you do not have a dual extruder) at the first layer after the thickness of your card. Here's a YouTube video to assist with this process: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6GGh4OTJ2Y

Duration

1-3 hours.

Preparation

You require filament and a 3D printer!

References

YouTube for FreeCAD tutorials. http://www.openscad.org/cheatsheet/ for OpenSCAD help.

Rubric & Assessment

The grade should be based on the students ability to successfully incorporate 3 lines of text.

comments.text: Nice work man.  I like the way you went further and learned OpenSCAD because you knew C!
comments.author: onebeartoe

comments.text: Thank you!
comments.author: onebeartoe

description.text:
Why more dice? Because I modeled freeware dice a while back and thought it'd be nice to print them.  
In this set only the six-sided die is represented. Two dice models are provided, one sized to 15mm and the other to 3/4 inch. Both have slightly rounded edges and modeled pips. Although they are somewhat easier to read than the photo indicates they would be easier to read with good markings.  
To round things out for those with dual extruders, the 15mm has three additional files: one with cylindrical pips and the other two for pips.  
Please note: as with any 3d printed dice these will only be as good as your printer. Your mileage may vary, but the ones I have printed are not accurate. For example, printing the 15mm d6 at 12mm the sides measured 11.73mm x 11.95mm by 11.91mm.

As I don't have a dual extruder I have not printed that version of the dice. I'd appreciate feedback from someone who does.  
To avoid the dice being too light they should be printed with 100% infill. If using Makerware you will need either v2.3 or create a profile that uses the grid infill: prior to v2.3 the hex fill type does not actually provide 100% infill and takes a long time as it tries to print minuscule hexes. This is corrected v2.3.  
They print as well as they're going to without need for a raft, but I printed directly on the acrylic plate to ensure good adhesion. Rotating them so that the 6-face is down will minimize the amount of surface in contact and may make removal easier.

print_settings.Notes:: Perimeter shells >= 3

description.text:
1/4" To 3/8" Socket Adapter

Scaling

Scale to the 1/4" side being a precise fit.
The 3/8 side has tabs that can be sanded down to make that a precise fit.

The exact dimension of the 1/4" side is .254 " This worked for my well calibrated printer. So I left it as is. The 3/8" (.375") is exactly .373" not including the tabs. This left it undersized on the flat part, and over-sized on the tabs. Some light sanding on the tabs gave a perfect fit.

IMPORTANT!
PLA Shatters when stressed, Print in ABS or I highly recommend PETG.

Ultimaker

No

Notes:

Perimeter shells >= 3

Sand

Sand the tabs on 3/8" side to fit.

These are an adapter for the GOXT 23024 Phone Mount to fix 6" phones. Specifically the Nexus 6P as I had a very hard time finding a new compatible one. These should slide on just like the original pieced the mount comes with.

This is now tested and I can confirm that the measurements are spot on. I was able to install these pegs with just enough resistance to keep them in place without them slipping out. However you will need to add craft foam to the parts that make contact with the phone or it will just slip out.

title: Raspberry PI B+ and Pi 2 Case - Configurable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A case for Raspberry PI B+ and Raspberry PI 2 computer boards. The cover snaps on to the base, and holds the Raspberry PI board securely. No screws are necessary.

The provided STL files provide access to all components on the Raspberry PI board.

This case can be configured in various combinations, providing access to the Raspberry PI components. In addition, there's a vent around the top which can be configured to various heights. And for those adventurous enough, there are variables in the script that can be changed, including wall thickness, etc. (Look below function main() for the variables.)

This design can be changed on-line at the Z3D Laboratory
